Award.AwardTitle: Smart gate membranes for highly selective removal of carbon dioxide from combustion gases
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical Abstract:
This project focuses on the development of fundamental science enabling fabrication of porous membranes for N2/CO2 separation with high selectivity and significant fluxes. High selectivity is achieved by inducing different molecular transport mechanisms for different components in a gas mixture. This research has a transformative impact because no microporous membranes have been demonstrated so far where selectivity is achieved by inducing different transport mechanisms for different components inside a membrane. The gas transport mechanisms on microscopic length scales will be monitored by a unique nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) technique. The separation approach developed in this project can be easily adapted for other industrially important gas separations using the same membrane.

Technical Abstract:
The objective of this project is to develop structure-property relationships that will enable the fabrication of microporous membranes for N2/CO2 separation with high selectivity, which are achieved by selective induction of single-file diffusion to N2 molecules. The research effort is split between the following tasks: (1) fabrication of membrane supports with nanopore diameters below 5 nm and (2) characterization of the diffusion properties of gas mixtures in these membranes. Application of a unique diffusion NMR technique enables distinguishing between different diffusion mechanisms for different gas components inside the membrane on the microscopic length scales. Successful completion of the proposed research affords a transformative membrane-based technology to separate CO2 from combustion gas mixtures. The research plan is integrated with a recruitment program and supervised research for undergraduate students, especially students from the underrepresented groups, as well as mentoring and outreach. The students will be trained to use a unique diffusion NMR technique at the National High Magnetic Field Laboratory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
While porous membranes have already found some important applications, their integration into gas-phase separations has been limited by the selectivities of the membranes. Restricting the transport of a selected component in a mixture to single-file diffusion within the porous channels has the potential to achieve remarkable selectivities (> 1000) if the normal diffusion mechanism is preserved for other components. However, fabricating these one-dimensional channels with diameters in the range of gas molecules has been difficult and limited the progress of this approach. The goal of this project was to develop structure-property relationships that will enable the fabrication of smart gate membranes with high selectivities and significant fluxes. Our main objective has been to identify synthetic approaches that can achieve porous materials with diameters that are suitable for single-file diffusion. A key aspect of this objective is not only being able to synthesize materials with the correct dimensions but to be able to prepare it so that it can be measured by pulsed-field gradient (PFG) NMR. 

The outcomes from the support of NSF grant DMR-1709784 has advanced the field in the development of porous materials at dimensions approaching 1 nm.

Anodic aluminum oxide (AAO), which is a porous nanomaterial fabricated in the presence of an electric field, can have a wide range of pore diameter, interpore distance, and thickness, depending on the electrolyte, electric potential, and temperature. One aspect of this process that makes it appealing to this research is the ability to produce well-ordered porous templates over macroscopic areas, with the limiting factor being the size of the reaction vessel. Anodization has been shown to produce porous materials with large scale ordering and pore sizes of 10 nm. We have shown that controlling the electric field during anodization can generate pores in the sub 5 nm range, with some below 2 nm in diameter. These 2 nm pores are near the limit of the anodization process because it is approximately equal to the sum of the hydrated radii of the ions involved in the reaction.

An important requirement for the porous materials is that they must be fabricated with macroscopic dimensions so that single-file diffusion can be adequately characterized through PFG NMR. A specific class of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) were chosen due to its one-dimensional channels with sub 1 nm pores that do not exhibit a strong response to a magnetic field applied in NMR studies. We have demonstrated the ability to increase the average crystal size by adapting different reaction times, calcination times, calcination temperatures, and cooling profiles.

Finally, azobenzene (AB) moieties were incorporated into thiol-ene networks (TENs). The AB-modified TENs showed incorporation of AB into the networks. Although full incorporation was not achieved, there were changes in both the physical state/color and thermal properties.

In addition, the NSF support contributed to the training of several students, including five doctoral students, two masters students, and 2 undergraduate students during this 1-year project.
